awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of innovations to authenticate multimedia objects to be used as evidence in legal proceedings. Digital media admitted as legal evidence must meet court-defined values for authenticity, integrity, and veracity. Moreover, deep fakes or multimedia content that has been partially or completely computer-generated with the intent to deceive has progressed to a level where detection in some cases is beyond the ability of humans to achieve unassisted. In the legal public sector, this technology may be leveraged by a judge or court or used to gather evidence by the police, prosecutor, FBI, or other government entity. On the private side, its use is not only in courtrooms but in depositions, or during eDiscovery, a process already used for vetting electronic documents like email. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of new technology to possibly detect audio-visual forgeries, including various types of deep fakes used in the manipulation and/or falsification of digital multimedia. Existing Forensic Examiners typically do not satisfy the requirements of criminal justice and social media platforms; they are limited in scope and are unable to answer complex questions regarding the nature of the forgery. This is particularly true when the media is recorded using low-powered devices and/or has been subjected to an anti-forensic attack. Unlike the state-of-the-art tools which rely on deep learning algorithms for pattern matching to detect single forgeries (e.g., video or voice deep fakes), this innovation uses a multimodal and neuro-symbolic artificial intelligence (AI) approach, and could detect multiple complex audiovisual forgeries, including deep fakes by performing the deep inspection at the file- and frame- levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This I-Corps project explored an urgent, unmet need to develop powerful techniques to detect audiovisual deepfake attacks. Although the initial focus of our product Deep Forgery Detector (DFD) is on mitigating effects of audiovisual forgeries on the legal sector, the project is likely to benefit society at large, in national security, the media, politics, business, and science. Currently this need is met via expert witnesses, alone or in conjunction with existing detectors. This solution is laborious, suffers from lack of reproducibility, may be biased, and comes with considerable cost. By helping to bring the DFD to the marketplace, this project gives the public the ability to have faith in audiovisual content by giving it a source of truth to verify digital multimedia.  

 

There is a further need for analytic output from a detector like the DFD to possess a number of characteristics: 1) Authenticity – evaluation of the complete set of events leading to the malicious content, 2) Integrity – detection of all the means of attack utilized, 3) Veracity – the forensic model used must be unbiased (fair) and the process be readily understood, and 4) Readability – the analytic report should not require an expert to decipher the results.

 

The DFD addresses all of these concerns and takes a multiplex approach to audio and video forgeries including Deepfake detection.  As such, it will be an invaluable asset to judicial systems, government offices, and social media sites. No other forensic-examiner offers AI-based written multimedia forensic reports, or dialog based on these reports, to the legal community taking only multimedia files as an input. Likewise, no product aims to detect at once shallow-, deep-fakes, and complex forgeries, such as manual manipulation on top of created deepfake, and separate manipulation of the audio.

 

To ensure long-term sustainability, we formed a start-up company and submitted, and received, a NSF Partnership for Innovation (PFI) award. The team further plans to submit an NSF SBIR/STTR proposal to enhance the development of the DFD technology. Plans to develop a Graphic User Interface (GUI) for the minimum viable product (MVP) will be executed following the outcome of additional customer discovery from sectors other than legal one explored in this I-Corps project.

 

Customer discovery will also shape our exploration of licensing plans with several companies who have expressed interest. These licensing plans will depend on type of forgeries, modality of the media, required type of supported users, and other yet to be determined objectives. We are having exploratory conversations with commercial partners who are willing to help fund development efforts for the DFD, and plan to expand these partnerships during the I-Corps experience.

 

The DFD I-Corps project was completed to the satisfaction of all participants. The team was able to successfully navigate the I-Corps training process, completing more than 100 interviews during the intensive course, and using the remainder of the funds completed more than 100 more. After I-Corps, the team was also able to attend several conferences and conducted extensive product and market research. While customer discovery remains an ongoing project, the funding for the National Science Foundation was extraordinarily valuable in securing a good foundation for our product going forward.

 

The team remains hopeful the DFD is a viable opportunity. With the business relationships the team initiated with this NSF funding, we are hopeful to be able to execute the market strategies learned through the I-Corps training. The team has made inroads both nationally and internationally, with corporate and municipal parties both interested in the final product, and development on the DFD continues in the hope of creating a MVP by Q1 2025. The team continues to use the skills learned in the I-Corps training to use the techniques learned to secure new business relationships, investors, and even new team members, for the DFD project.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2024
Modified by: Khalid M Malik
